In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can define a function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    # Lowercase the string
    col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespace
    col = strip(col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    col = replace(col, r"\s|-" => "_")
    
    return col
end
```

This function `clean_column` takes a string (`AbstractString`) as input and returns the cleaned version of the column name. It first lowercases the string, then strips any leading or trailing whitespace using `strip()`, which is a built-in Julia function that removes both leading and trailing whitespace from the string. Finally, it replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores using `replace()`, which is also a built-in function for replacing patterns in strings.

You can use this function to clean column names as follows:

```julia
julia> col_name = "My Column"
"My Column"

julia> clean_column(col_name)
"my_column"
```

In the example above, `clean_column` is applied to a string called `col_name`, and it returns the cleaned version of the column name.
